habitat: Lowland tropical forests and dry forests to humid upland forests.
basic_id_cues: A medium-sized snake (avg length 2m) that has two color variations; grayish-green and yellow, orange and brown. Blotches and patterns with darker colors along the entire body.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Madagascar Boas.The international trade in this species is prohibited, the animal is threatened by loss of habitat, and is only found in Madagascar.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. For this species, all international trade in live animals or body parts is prohibited. Examine each case for further investigative leads and proper documentation.
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. Advise caution, as the animal is highly dangerous. Request expert veterinary assistance. Contain and do not approach until veterinarians or expert handlers arrive.
traded_as: Mainly for use in the pet trade and for their hides.
common_trafficking: Often transported in sacks. Endangered snakes are often disguised as more common species. Also transported as juveniles and eggs.
notes: Some believe that the color variations could be separate species.
disease_name: Bacterial infections: Salmonellosis, Aeromonas, Edwardsiella, Campylobacter, Pseudomonas, Mycobacterium Ulcerans, E. coli

habitat: Mangroves, agricultural areas, bamboo thickets and forests, usually near streams. Also paddy fields and swamps.
basic_id_cues: A medium-sized snake with a distinct moncellate (O) mark on the rear of the hood. Colors range from olive to brown with the underbelly being the same color only more pale. The snake can enlarge its neck to form a hood when threatened.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Monocellate Cobras. The international trade is regulated and the animal is extremely dangerous.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. For this species all international trade is heavily regulated. National laws for its protection exist in certain countries. Ensure all documentation is genuine. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report.
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. This snake is extremely dangerous and poisonous. Contain and wait for expert handlers to arrive.
traded_as: Used extensively for food, snake wine, its skin, and a number of uses in traditional Chinese medicine.
common_trafficking: Often transported in sacks. Endangered snakes are often disguised as more common species. Also transported as juveniles and eggs.
disease_name: Bacterial infections: Salmonellosis, Aeromonas, Edwardsiella, Campylobacter, Pseudomonas, Mycobacterium Ulcerans, E. coli

habitat: Low lying plains and forest regions, open fields, grasslands, and agricultural areas.
basic_id_cues: Medium length snake. Able to expand ribs into hood when threatened. The head is elliptical, depressed, slightly distinct from neck with a short, rounded snout and large nostrils.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Northern Philippine Cobras. This snake is exploited for its meat, skin and is often used in traditional Chinese medicine or in wine. Also, the animal is extremely dangerous and poisonous.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to authorities.
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. This snake is extremely dangerous and poisonous. Contain and wait for expert handlers to arrive.
traded_as: Hunted for its skin and its meat.
common_trafficking: Often transported in sacks. Endangered snakes are often disguised as more common species. Also transported as juveniles and eggs.
disease_name: Bacterial infections: Salmonellosis, Aeromonas, Edwardsiella, Campylobacter, Pseudomonas, Mycobacterium Ulcerans, E. coli

habitat: Lowlands, hills, plains, and woodland.
basic_id_cues: Medium-sized cobra with a thick body. The body color of this species can range from gray to brown to black, with white spots or stripes. Sometimes there will be large sections of white on the snake. Can form a hood.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Indochinese Spitting Cobras. This snakes is exploited for its meat, skin ans is often used in traditional Chinese medicine or in wine. Also, the animal is extremely dangerous and poisonous.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. For this species all international trade is heavily regulated. National laws in certain countries exist. Ensure all documentation is genuine. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to authorities.
known_as: Thai Spitting Cobra, Black-and-white Spitting Cobra
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. This snake is extremely dangerous and poisonous. Contain and wait for expert handlers to arrive.
traded_as: Used extensively for food, snake wine, its skin and a number of uses in traditional Chinese medicine.

habitat: Wetlands, marshes, swamps, large muddy rivers, lower elevations.
basic_id_cues: Brown and black colored turtle with yellow dots on its head and neck. The carapace (shell) is soft, unlike those of other turtles. Nose is trunk-like and very straight. Rounded carapace (top shell) features a rough texture with small bumps at the front, above the neck. The underside of the turtle is plain white.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY. The Asiatic shoftshell is exploited for trade as food, juveniles for the pet trade and also for use in traditional Chinese medicine. The species is considered vulnerable and international trade is heavily regulated. Report trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. Asiatic Softshell turtles may only be traded/transported internationally with a valid CITES permit. This species also occurs in protected areas and national protections may also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to authorities.
similar_animals: Malaysian softshell turtle
known_as: Asiatic Softshell Turtle, Southeast Asian soft terrapin
first_responder:
Avoid handling turtles until experts and veterinarians arrive. Wear gloves when necessary. 
This species is a strong biter and capable of badly injuring human fingers. The egg yolks are easily broken in the female’s body (characterized by a higher carapace, or upper shell) during rough handling and transport, and can lead to mortality. Internally wounded individuals need to receive expert veterinary attention as soon as possible before they die.
traded_as: Live or eggs
common_trafficking: Shipped by truck, boat and air freight. Specimens are often transported in plastic sacks. Specimens can be transported live or as eggs. Often concealed on persons or in luggage. Fake documents purporting the legal shipment are common.
disease_name: Bacterial infections: Salmonellosis, Aeromonasis, Campylobacteriosis,Pseudomonas, Mycobacterium spp.

habitat: Shallow ocean waters throughout the Pacific and Indian oceans and sandy beaches for nesting.
basic_id_cues: The smallest of the marine turtles, the carapace (shell) is olive colored and slightly heart-shaped. The turtle has more than 5 bony plates (scutes) along the shell which distinguishes it from the closely related Kemp's Ridley turtle which only has 5. The skin of this species is olive-gray. Each of the four limbs has two claws.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Olive Ridley Turtles. These turtles are listed as vulnerable because their numbers are decreasing and they only nest at 5 places in the world. The international trade of this species is prohibited. Report trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. For this species, all international trade in live animals, or body parts is illegal. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. Examine each case for further investigative leads and report.
similar_animals: Kemps Ridley Turtle, Green Turtle, Loggerhead Turtle
first_responder: Avoid handling turtles until experts and veterinarians arrive.This species moves quickly, and is a strong biter capable of badly injuring human fingers (especially the adults). They can be kept in a salt water pond (sometimes cemented pond) temporarily.
traded_as: Mainly for its meat and eggs.
common_trafficking: Shipped by truck, boat and air freight. Specimens are often transported in plastic sacks. Specimens can be transported live, or their eggs. Often concealed on persons or in luggage. Fake documents purporting legal shipment are common.
disease_name: Bacterial infections: Salmonellosis, Aeromonasis, Campylobacteriosis, Pseudomonas, Mycobacterium spp.

habitat: Oceans throughout the world. Sandy tropical beaches for nesting.
basic_id_cues: The carapace (shell) of this sea turtle is heart-shaped with a hump towards the rear third and reddish-brown, and the plastron (underbelly) is yellowish. This turtle has a large head with powerful jaws. The skin ranges from yellow to brown in color. Five scales down each side of the carapace, and two pairs of scales between the eyes.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Loggerhead turtles or their byproducts. This species is listed as endangered. Habitat loss is considered the major threat faced by this species.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. For this species, all international trade of live animals or body parts is illegal. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. Examine each case for further investigative leads and report to authorities.
similar_animals: Green Turtle, Olive Ridley Turtle, Kemps Ridley Turtle
first_responder: Avoid handling turtles until experts and veterinarians arrive. Wear gloves when necessary. This species is a strong biter and capable to badly injure human fingers. The egg yolks are easily broken in the female’s body (characterized by a higher carapace, or upper shell) during rough handling and transport, and can lead to mortality. Internally wounded individuals need to receive expert veterinary attention as soon as possible before they die. Specimens are often transported in plastic sacks, and can be captured in nets. They can be kept in a saltwater pond (sometimes cemented) temporarily.
traded_as: Mainly for its eggs. The meat is not considered a delicacy although it is consumed by some populations.
common_trafficking: Shipped by truck, boat and air freight. Specimens are often transported in plastic sacks. Specimens can be transported live or their eggs. Often concealed on persons or in luggage. Counterfeit documents purporting the legal shipment are common.
disease_name: Bacterial infections: Salmonellosis, Aeromonasis, Campylobacteriosis, Pseudomonas, Mycobacterium spp.

habitat: Estuaries in tidal areas, mangrove swamps and creeks.
basic_id_cues: One of Asia's largest fresh water turtles. The carapace (shell) is brown but body color varies from light green to black. This turtle has a distinct snout-shaped nose.The juveniles have a distinct ridge along the shell which disappears with age.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY River Terrapins. These turtles are listed as critically endangered and are exploited for use in Asian food markets. The River Terrapin is regionally extinct in Myanmar, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam. Report trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. For this species, all international trade in live animals or body parts is prohibited. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. Examine each case for further investigative leads and report.
similar_animals: Red crowned roofed turtle, Three striped roof turtle, Burmese roofed turtle
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. Handle with extreme care: egg yolks are easily broken in the female’s body during rough handling or transport. Egg-carrying females are characterized by a higher carapace, or upper shell. Specimens in trade can have their shells broken and be internally wounded. These are very difficult to save and require expert veterinary assessment, which may call for specialized care. During handling and shipment, they maybe deliberately starved to avoid production of faeces in the container. They will not survive long without food so it is essential these animals are placed in specialized veterinary care immediately. Ensure ventilation, but do not remove until a better holding environment can be found. Suspected captive bred or non-native specimens should not be released into the wild.
traded_as: Mainly for meat and its eggs.
common_trafficking: Shipped by truck, boat and air freight. Specimens are often transported in plastic sacks. Specimens can be transported live or their eggs. Often concealed on persons or in luggage. Counterfeit documents purporting the legal shipment are common.
disease_name: Bacterial infections: Salmonellosis, Aeromonasis, Campylobacteriosis, Pseudomonas, Mycobacterium spp.

habitat: Estuaries in tidal areas, mangrove swamps and creeks.
basic_id_cues: The shell (carapace) of this turtle is oval and gray-brown to green in color with black patches. On the head of males there are distinct red markings which only appear during the mating season. This Terrapin has a snout-shaped nose. The underbelly is lighter in color and yellow.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Painted Terrapins. This species is considered critically endangered and could possibly be extinct in Thailand. The painted terrapin is heavily exploited for is eggs for use in Asian food markets. Habitat loss is another threat faced by this species.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. For this species, all international trade in live animals, or body parts is heavily regulated. Examine documentation carefully. Examine each case for further investigative leads and report.

enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. For this species, all international trade of live animals or body parts is heavily regulated. Examine documentation carefully. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to trusted authorities.

habitat: Dry low lying forests, under leaf litter and in shrubs.
basic_id_cues: Small tortoise with relatively flat (not domed) carapace (shell) and flat tail. Dark greenish to black in color with distinct yellowish markings on the shell. Each scute has a brown to yellow center with distinct  dark borders, usually square and surrounded by another yellow border. The underbelly (plastron) is yellow with variable dark blotches or spots.The limbs range from brown to yellow and the hind legs have scales.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Flat-tailed Tortoises. This species is considered critically endangered and is only found in Madagascar. This species is threatened by habitat loss and exploitation for the pet trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. For this species, all international trade of live animals or body parts is prohibited. This species is also protected under national law. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. Examine each case for further investigative leads and report.

habitat: Arid grasslands and bushes. Some can be found in wetter area of Africa but only rarely.
basic_id_cues: A tortoise with a very distinct leopard pattern on the carapace (shell). The limbs and head are cream to brown in color. The shell is usually a light yellow color surrounded by darker bands to form rings around the scutes. Each individual is marked uniquely making this species difficult to identify.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Leopard Tortoises. This species is considered vulnerable. The importation into the U.S. is prohibited. Report trade.
enforcement_advice: No laws exist except it is banned from import by the USDA. Report trade.

extant_countries: Bhutan, Brunei Darussalam, China, India, Nepal, Sri Lanka
habitat: This species occurs in moist or semi-evergreen forest in lowlands, hills and mountains.
basic_id_cues: A medium size bird black in color. Two distinct yellow stripes on either side of the head. A bright orange bill and yellow legs. When in flight white patches on the wings are visible.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Hill Mynas. International trade for this species is regulated. Populations are declining due to the extreme exploitation of this bird for its ability to mimic. Report trade to authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE.  International trade is regulated. Examine all documents thoroughly and seek expert advice if necessary. National protections may also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads.
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. Always wear gloves and a mask when handling birds. Perches should be provided as it is almost entirely arboreal. They are omnivores which can eat insects, fruit and nectar.
traded_as: Live animals for pet trade.
common_trafficking: Birds are commonly trafficked as eggs or as sedated animals. Sometimes secreted on the smuggler's body in specially made pockets/pouches. Also found in suitcases, usually packed tightly into small plastic or cardboard cylinders/pipes. Also transported in cages, usually covered, by boat or land vehicle.
disease_name: Avian Influenza, Chlamydiosis, Histoplasmosis, Newcastle Disease, Salmonellosis, West Nile Virus

habitat: Primary forest and forest edges in most lowland areas
basic_id_cues: The smallest of the lories at around 25 cm. This parrot is mainly red with distinct blue feathers that run from the eye to just past the ear. Blue and black feathers are also on the wings and tail. The Blue-eared lorikeet has an orange beak.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY. The population of Blue-eared Lorikeet is decreasing.The international trade of this species is heavily regulated and national protections may apply. The Blue-eared Lorikeet is heavily exploited for the pet trade. Report trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE.  International trade is highly regulated and requires a CITES permit. Examine all documents thoroughly and seek expert advice if necessary. National protections may also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report.
similar_animals: Red-and-blue Lory, Violet-necked lory, red lory, blue-streaked lory, black-winged lory
known_as: Blue-eared Lorikeet, Ceram Lory, Half-masked Lory, and Seram Lory
first_responder: Lorikeets don’t always get along with other birds in captivity; they can become very aggressive if they think their territory or perceived possessions are threatened. Keep isolated, where possible. Lorikeets can be kept in a cage covered by a cloth. Keep away from dogs, snakes, and other potential predators.
traded_as: Harvested extensively for the pet trade.
common_trafficking: Birds are commonly trafficked as eggs or as sedated animals. Sometimes secreted on the smuggler's body in specially made pockets/pouches. Also found in suitcases, usually packed tightly into small plastic or cardboard cylinders/pipes. Also transported in cages, usually covered, by boat or land vehicle.
disease_name: Psittacosis, Salmonella, Campylobacter, Newcastle disease, Avian TB, Allergic Alveolitis,West Nile virus, Avian Influenza, Mycobacterium, Aspergillus fumigatus

habitat: Dry forests in India; however, it has been spotted in more tropical forests on the edge of its range.
basic_id_cues: Square-headed owl with a dark grey-brown crown and nape with faintly spotted white. The Forest Owlet has distinct bright yellow eyes. The wings are broadly banded blackish-brown and white. Broadly banded tail with white tail-tip. Dark brown breast with broad prominent barring on flanks, white underparts.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Forest Owlet. This species was thought to be extinct until rediscovered in 1997. There are fewer than 100 confirmed individuals. This owl is considered critically endangered and all international trade is prohibited. Report trade to trusted authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. No legal international trade in Forest Owlet is permitted. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. National protections also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to trusted authorities.
similar_animals: Usambara Eagle-owl, Brown Fish-owl, Christmas Hawk-owl
known_as: Forest Little Owl, Forest Spotted Owlet
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. Standard gauntlet for restraint. Beak will inflict superficial injury, talons will also cause injury. The bird can be restrained by one person holding in the wings and keeping the feet away from one's body. Covering the head will help keep the bird calm. No perch in box.
traded_as: Live animals, body parts for traditional medicine/magic.
common_trafficking: Birds are commonly trafficked as eggs or as sedated animals. Sometimes secreted on the smugglers body in specially made pockets/pouches. Also found in suitcases, usually packed tightly into small plastic or cardboard cylinders/pipes. Also transported in cages, usually covered, by boat or land vehicle.
disease_name: West Nile virus, avian influenza, Mycobacterium, Aspergillus fumigatus.

extant_countries: Australia, Bangladesh, India, Mozambique, Papua New Guinea, South Africa, Sri Lanka
habitat: Shallow coastal, estuaries, and fresh waters.
basic_id_cues: A large sawfish with a short saw which is broad-based and possesses 14 to 22 very big teeth on each side. Has a shark-like body and gill slits on their ventral side. The animal is predominately colored grey with a lighter colored underside.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Freshwater Sawfish, their parts or derivative products. International trade or transport of Freshwater Sawfish, their parts and derived products is illegal. Freshwater Sawfish are classified as critically endangered as a result of over-fishing, habitat loss and degradation. Report trade to trusted authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. International trade in wild caught sawfish is illegal. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. National protections also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to trusted authorities.
similar_animals: Dwarf sawfish, smalltooth sawfish, and green sawfish
known_as: Freshwater Sawfish, Largetooth Sawfish, Leichhardts Sawfish, Smalltooth Sawfish
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. Approach with caution, due to the powerful size of the animal.
traded_as: Rostrum, fins, liver used for traditional medicine, and meat.
common_trafficking: Packed in water-filled plastic bags or tubs. Fish are commonly smuggled with other non-protected species.
disease_name: Potential for parasites if consuming undercooked meat nematode: C. philippinensis, G. Hipidium Trematode: C. sinensis, O. viverrini Cestode: D. latum, Bacterial infections from contaminated water: Vibriosis, Mycobacteriosis, Aeromonasis, Pseudomoniasis, Campylobacter, Erysipelas, Leptosprirosis, Botulism, Edwardsiella, E. coli, salmonellosis.

habitat: Shallow coastal, estuarine, and fresh waters. Mainstreams rivers, from upper to middle reaches, rarely lower reaches.
basic_id_cues: A large fish unique for its colorful body pattern with seven dark stripes that run down the body. The upper surface is a brownish color, and the underside is a silvery white. In addition, the fins are an luminescent blue, and the head  a mix of gold and blue. The eyes are orange.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY. Jullien's Golden Carp, their parts or derivative products. International trade or transport of Jullien's Golden Carp, their parts and derived products is illegal. Report trade to trusted authorities. Jullien's Golden Carp are classified as endangered, as a result of over-fishing, habitat loss and fragmentation.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. International trade in wild caught Jullien's Golden Carp is illegal. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. National protections also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report.
known_as: Julliens Golden Carp, Seven-striped Barb, Isok Barb, Barbeau De Jullien, or Carpilla Ikan Temoleh
average_size_weight: Can reach Length ~150 cm and weight ~70kg
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily.
traded_as: Pets, meat

Hipidium Trematode: C. sinensis, O. viverrini Cestode: D. latum, Bacterial infections from contaminated water: Vibriosis, Mycobacteriosis, Aeromonasis, Pseudomoniasis, Campylobacter, Erysipelas, Leptosprirosis, Botulism, Edwardsiella, E. coli, salmonellosis.

habitat: Warm tropical waters on reefs to a depth up to 20 meters
basic_id_cues: Small to very small marine creature which resembles a horse, giving them their name. Colors can range from pale browns to really bright various patterns including spots, stripes and many other variations.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY  Seahorses, their parts or derivative products. All species of seahorse are protected. International trade or transport of the seahorse is heavily regulated and may be illegal in some nations. Report trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. The international trade of all seahorse species is heavily regulates and requires a CITES permit. Examine all documents to ensure they are genuine. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report.
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. Contact experts for handling.
traded_as: Pets, traditional Chinese medicine
common_trafficking: Packed in water-filled plastic bags or tubs. Seahorses are often dried before transport.

habitat: Savannah and forests throughout Australia.
basic_id_cues: A small pink and grey parrot. The eyes of the females are red while the males are brown. The breast and head feathers are pink while the feathers on the wings and back are grey.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Galahs. The international trade of this parrot is regulated. This species is also exploited for the pet trade. Report.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. The international trade in this species is strictly regulated and requires a CITES permit. Examine all documents to ensure they are genuine. Report.
known_as: Pink and Grey Cockatoo, red breasted Cockatoo, roseate Cockatoo, rose breasted Cockatoo.
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. Always wear a mask and gloves when dealing with birds.
traded_as: Live animals for the pet trade.
common_trafficking: Birds are commonly trafficked as eggs or as sedated animals. Sometimes secreted on the smuggler's body in specially made pockets/pouches. Also found in suitcases, usually packed tightly into small plastic or cardboard cylinders/pipes. Also transported in cages, usually covered, by boat or land vehicle.
disease_name: Psittacosis, Salmonella, Campylobacter, Newcastle disease, Avian TB, Allergic Alveolitis, West Nile virus, Avian influenza, Mycobacterium, Aspergillus fumigatus.

habitat: All habitats
basic_id_cues: A diverse family of flowers consisting of more than 20,000 species, all of which are protected. Orchids can be found in many habitats. Orchids are easily distinguished from other plants, as they share some very evident apomorphies. Among these are: bilateral symmetry (zygomorphism), many resupinate flowers, a nearly always highly modified petal (labellum), fused stamens and carpels, and extremely small seeds.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Orchids that come from the wild. All wild orchids are protected from national trade. Wild orchids are easy to distinguish as they will have minor defects, and not look as "perfect" as one that was farmed.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. All wild orchids require CITES permits (seedlings or tissue cultures are exempt). Determining the origin of orchids is key to determining if a violation has occurred. International trade of wild harvested orchids is illegal. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. Seek expert identification assistance for cases involving orchids. Examine each case for further investigative leads.
first_responder: Avoid handling unnecessarily and keep in isolation. Orchids should be handled by specialists
traded_as: Collectibles for enthusiasts, or as founding stock for cloning in nurseries.
common_trafficking: Smuggled by air and overland, often in boxes or other containers, including plastic drums.
notes: Seedling or tissue cultures obtained in vitro, in solid or liquid media, and transported in sterile containers are not subject to the provisions of the Convention.

habitat: Rainforests, swamp forests, mangrove forests, monsoonal forests, woodlands, subalpine shrubbery, tropical mountains, disturbed habitats .
basic_id_cues: An orchid with a long lasting flower. The pointed outer petals are creamy white. The center of the flower is red giving this species its common name.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY or transport Blood Red Dendrobiums or any orchid internationally unless confident it's been artificially propagated, and is therefore legal. All wild orchids are protected from trade. The blood red dendrobium Orchid is nearing extinction in the wild. Report trade to trusted authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. All wild orchids require CITES permits (seedlings or tissue cultures are exempt). Determining the origin of orchids is key to determining if a violation has occurred. International trade of wild harvested Blood Red Dendrobium Orchids is illegal. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. Seek expert identification assistance for cases involving orchids. Examine each case for further investigative leads.

habitat: Wet forests
basic_id_cues: One of the many lady slipper orchids which resemble a shoe. This species has a distinct dark green 'slipper'. The three petals have purple-to-pink edges with black stripes and spots.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY or transport Pointed Tooth Paphiopedilums or any orchid internationally unless confident, it's been artificially propagated, and is therefore legal. All wild orchids are protected from trade. The Pointed Tooth Paphiopedilum is only found in the Philippines. Report trade to trusted authorities.

habitat: Mixed forests in Southeast Asia
basic_id_cues: A tree found in Southeast Asia with a dark reddish wood and smooth bark. Siamese rosewood also has a distinct smell.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Siamese rosewood or any of its products. This species is protected from international trade. Siamese rosewood is being poached from the forest at alarming rates by well armed poachers leading to many deaths of forest rangers. Report trade to trusted authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. International trade of Siamese rosewood is heavily regulated. Many national protections also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report.
first_responder: Avoid handling unnecessarily.
traded_as: Used for furniture, musical instruments and other household items.
common_trafficking: Smuggled out of the forest on buggies or floated down creeks. Secreted in various vehicles for road transport.

habitat: High altitude shrublands
basic_id_cues: A wide carnivorous pitcher plant, purple and green in color. Its large and bell-shaped structure has a distinct small lid that is also green and purple.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Attenborough's Pitcher Plants. All wild pitcher plants are protected from international trade. This species is endangered and is only found in one small area in the wild, making this plant very vulnerable. Report trade to authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. International trade of wild Attenborough's Pitcher Plant is prohibited. Many national protections also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to authorities.

habitat: Shallow pools, swamps, slow-moving water.
basic_id_cues: Bright orange to red colored frog with dark lines on either side of the body and pale underside. Back may have darker speckles. Females are much larger than males.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY. Tomato frogs do not make suitable pets, and should not be handled. In the wild, they are not found outside Madagascar. It is illegal to trade or transport these frogs internationally. Report trade to trusted authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. No legal international trade in the Tomato Frog is permitted. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report.
similar_animals: Southern / False Tomato Frog
average_size_weight: Male length ~6cm weight ~40g Female Length ~9cm weight ~200g
first_responder: Avoid handling unless necessary. Wear sterile gloves. Tomato frogs are known to produce a sticky, white glue like substance when threatened which can cause an allergic reaction in humans. Tomato frogs have delicate skin, handle with care. Must have access to small dish with water.
traded_as: Mainly for the pet trade.
common_trafficking: Transported in small containers or jars with air holes.
disease_name: Bacterial infections including Salmonella and E. Coli.

habitat: Tropical forests, streams
basic_id_cues: A frog that is bright yellow or gold in color and has distinct black markings on most individuals. Females are larger than males. The first two fingers on each limb are webbed. The frog secretes a toxin, but is not considered extremely poisonous.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Panamanian Golden Frogs. This species is considered critically endangered. This species is not only threatened by over-collection for the international pet trade but also by Chytridiomycosis, a fungus which kills frogs. The international trade of this species is prohibited. Report trade to trusted authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. No legal international trade in the Panamanian golden frogs is permitted. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to authorities.
known_as: Panamanian Golden Frog, Golden Arrow Poison Frog, Golden Frog, Zetek's Golden Frog.
average_size_weight: Male length ~4cm weight ~10g Female length~ 5CM Weight ~12g
first_responder: Avoid handling unless necessary. Use caution when handling as they are capable of producing toxins on their skin that are potentially harmful to humans. Males are territorial and should be kept separate from each other. They prefer cooler water.
traded_as: Mainly for the pet trade
common_trafficking: Transported in small containers or jars with air holes
disease_name: Bacterial infections including Salmonella and E. Coli.

consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Green and Black Poison Frogs. Not only is handling this species dangerous but it is threatened by exploitation for the pet trade and habitat loss. Report trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. The international trade is strictly regulated and requires a valid CITES permit. Seek expert identification assistance if unable to identify this species. Examine each case for further investigative leads. National protections apply in some countries. Report.

In Panamá and in the Costa Rica border disappears the blue coloration of the hind legs, while the dorsal coloration varies from red-brown to green with several black spots. Some individuals are completely red lacking the characteristic blue legs. Some specimens can have black blotches or spots on the back.

consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY poison frogs. It can be very dangerous to handle this species. This species is considered endangered and is protected from international trade. The frogs are threatened by habitat loss.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. The international trade is strictly regulated and requires a valid CITES permit. Seek expert identification assistance if unable to identify this species. Examine each case for further investigative leads. National protections apply in some countries. Report.

habitat: Tropical rainforest.
basic_id_cues: A Tree Frog with large, bright, red eyes. The skin is green on the back with blue sides which extend down the top part of each limb. The blue sides are broken by yellow stripes. The feet and toes are orange. The belly is white. Females are larger than males.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Red-eyed Tree Frogs. This species is threatened by habitat loss and exploitation for the international pet trade. Report trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. The international trade is strictly regulated and requires a valid CITES permit. Seek expert identification assistance if unable to identify this species. Examine each case for further investigative leads. National protections apply in some countries. Report.
known_as: Red-Eyed Leaf Frog, Gaudy Leaf Frog,
first_responder: Avoid handling if possible. Extremely delicate skin and sensitive to stress. Must be kept in a vertical enclosure with high humidity and shelter. Prefers crickets and other invertebrates as food. Survives best when grouped with others. Zoonautic disease risk.
traded_as: Mainly for the pet trade.
common_trafficking: Transported in small containers or jars with air holes.
disease_name: Bacterial infections including Salmonella and E. Coli.

habitat: Open woodlands in Zagros Mountains, streams
basic_id_cues: A colorful red, orange, white and black in color. Patterns can vary between specimens, but all have a distinct orange line which runs the length of the back. The limbs are also orange with white and black spots and blotches on most of the body.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Emperor Spotted Newts. This species is critically endangered due to exploitation for the illegal pet trade. International trade of this species is prohibited. Report trade to trusted authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. The international trade of Emperor Spotted Newts is prohibited. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. National protection in Iran also exists. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to trusted authorities.
first_responder: Avoid handling if possible. Newts are capable of excreting toxins in skin secretions that may be harmful to humans. They prefer dim light and a relatively dry enclosure with access to freshwater. Extremely shy and prone to stress. Preferred food includes wax worms and mealworms.
traded_as: For the pet trade.
common_trafficking: Transported in small containers or jars with air holes.
disease_name: Bacterial infections including Salmonella and E. Coli.

extant_countries: Australia, New Caledonia, Papau New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Timor-Leste, Vanuatu
habitat: Tropical forests
basic_id_cues: A colorful parrot with mostly green plumage. The head is blue while the breast is orange to red. A yellow to orange nape can be found. The bill is red and the eyes are red. The head is deep blue with a greenish-yellow nuchal collar, and the rest of the upper parts are deep green. The chest is red with blue-black barring. The belly is deep green, and the thighs and rump are yellow with deep green barring. Juveniles have a black beak, which gradually brightens to orange in the adults.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Rainbow Lorikeets. The international trade for this species is regulated. This species is heavily exploited for the pet trade and wild-caught animals are disguised as captive-bred for sale in the pet trade. Report trade to authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. International trade is regulated. Examine all documents thoroughly and seek expert advice if necessary. National protections may also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads.
similar_animals: Blue-eared Lorikeet, Black-winged Lorikeet, Red Lorikeet, Violet-necked Lorikeet, Blue-streaked Lorikeet, Chattering Lorikeet, Black-capped Lorikeet
first_responder: Lorikeets don’t always get along with other birds in captivity; they can become very aggressive if they think their territory or perceived possessions are threatened. Keep isolated, where possible. Lorikeets can be kept in a cage covered by a cloth. Keep away from dogs, snakes, and other potential predators.
traded_as: Live animals for pet trade.
common_trafficking: Birds are commonly trafficked as eggs or as sedated animals. Sometimes concealed on the smuggler's body in specially made pockets/pouches. Also found in suitcases, usually packed tightly into small plastic or cardboard cylinders/pipes. Also transported in cages, usually covered, by boat or land vehicle.
disease_name: Psittacosis, Salmonella, Campylobacter, Newcastle Disease, Avian TB, Allergic Alveolitis, West Nile Virus, Avian Influenza, Mycobacterium, Aspergillus Fumigatus.

habitat: Arid lowlands and foothills, deciduous woodlands and dry open pine-oak forests.
basic_id_cues: Medium-sized green parrot with striking red forehead and blue stripes behind its eyes and down the sides of its neck. Also has distinguishable light green cheeks. Can have dark blue primary feathers and yellow tips on the outer tail feathers.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Red-crowned Amazon. This is an endangered species with severe population decline. The main threat to its survival is illegal export of trapped birds for the pet trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. No legal international trade in Red-crowned Amazon parrots is permitted. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. National protections also apply in some countries. Examine each case for further investigative leads.
known_as: Red-crowned Parrot, Green Cheeked Amazon, Mexican Red-headed Parrot
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. Bite risk. Very intelligent birds and are known to bite if threatened. Need proper enrichment and prefer an aviary or suspended cage. The are very social and inquisitive birds, and like to be in relatively large flocks.

common_trafficking: Birds are commonly trafficked as eggs or as sedated animals. Sometimes secreted on the smuggler's body in specially made pockets or pouches. habitat: Palm swamps, woodlands, semi-open wooded habitats.
basic_id_cues: This is the largest macaw and the largest of all flying parrot species. It has a long pointed tail and its feathers are entirely blue. It has a large curved black beak with bright yellow skin at the base as well as yellow encircling each eye.  Males and females appear identical.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Hyacinth Macaws. This is an endangered species that is experiencing dramatic population declines in the wild due to habitat loss and trapping for the pet trade.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. All international trade in the species is prohibited. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false and unlawful. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to authorities.
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily.  They have extremely powerful beaks and can deliver a serious bite. Caution should always be used around these birds although they are not normally aggressive. They need plenty of space for exercise and stimulation and are known to become phobic or neurotic when under stress or hygiene conditions are poor. Mortality rates of wild-caught macaws are extremely high. They have extremely specific dietary requirements. Contact an expert.

They have blue feathers on the edge of their wings and pale blue on their lower back. Their tail is tipped with red and pale blue. Eyes are pale yellow. Both sexes are similar.

enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. All international trade in the species is prohibited. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false and unlawful. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report.

Mortality rates of wild-caught macaws are extremely high. They have extremely specific dietary requirements. Contact an expert.

habitat: Sandy bottoms of large rivers and estuaries
basic_id_cues: An truly gigantic stingray possessing a large, whip-like tail and a venomous sting. Its upper surface is brown and its lower surface is a paler brown ringed on the edge by black. In addition, it has a broad, disk-shaped body and a large snout, but particularly small eyes.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY. Giant Freshwater Stingray, their parts, and derivative products. The Giant Freshwater Stingray is classified as vulnerable, as a result of fishing, habitat loss, habitat degradation, and habitat fragmentation.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. Examine individual cases for potential leads.
similar_animals: Bleekers Variegated Whip Ray, White-edge Freshwater Whip Ray, and Pink Whip Ray

first_responder: This is not an aggressive species but warrants caution as its sting is sheathed in toxic mucus and it can pierce bone. Avoid handling unless absolutely necessary.
traded_as: Meat
common_trafficking: Packed in water-filled plastic bags or tubs. Fish are commonly smuggled with other non-protected species.

habitat: Ranges across entire oceans in tropical and subtropical waters, prefers to remain far offshore.
basic_id_cues: This medium-sized shark species is known for its long, rounded pectoral and dorsal fins, rounded face and circular eyes. They have signature white tips on most of its fins and the fins can be mottled. The body is usually brown, bronze or gray. They have several different kinds of teeth, all serrated and triangular but varying in size.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY. Shark finning is in violation of the United Nations Code of Conduct for Responsible Fisheries and is a highly unsustainable practice. Shark fins are tasteless and meat contains high levels of methyl-mercury and other contaminants which can be extremely detrimental to your health. The World Health Organization advises against consumption of all shark products.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. Consult expert for identification purposes as some species of shark have protection under CITES Appendix II and III, as well as other national legislation. Report to authorities.
known_as: Brown Milberts Sand Bar Shark, Brown Shark, Nigano Shark, Whitetip Whaler, Whitetip Shark
first_responder: Avoid handling specimen. Report to authorities.
traded_as: Fins, meat, traditional Chinese medicine, shark oil for cosmetics and supplements.
common_trafficking: Taken commercially by long-line fisheries where the fin is most often cut off and the dismembered body discarded overboard. Imports and exports are largely unmonitored and unmanaged.
notes: Entry into effect September 14, 2014 this species will be listed under CITES Appendix II.

habitat: Lowland forests and wetlands
basic_id_cues: The Anoa is a small bovid that is thought to be related to the Asiatic Buffalo due to similar hair patterns on their back.  They have short, straight, upright horns.  They may have white markings on their legs and face and are usually dark brown in color.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Anoa, their parts or derivative products. This is an endangered species. Hunting for local consumption and parts for trade and habitat loss have decimated its population. International shipment of this species and any trade is strictly prohibited. Report to authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. No legal international trade in Anoa, their meat or parts is permitted. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. National protections also apply in Indonesia. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report.

habitat: Rugged hills at higher elevations.
basic_id_cues: The Chinese Serow is one of the largest of the Serows and is similar in shape to a goat. It has brown bristled hair with a short mane. Horns are only characteristic to males and are pale colored, short and curved backward.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Chinese Serow, their parts or derivative products. This is a threatened species. Hunting for local consumption and parts for trade and habitat loss has decimated its population. International shipment of this species and any trade is strictly prohibited. Serow are dangerous, costly and difficult to keep. They do not make appropriate pets. Serow derived medicines have no proven medicinal benefits. Disreputable Serow tourism operators have been linked to the trafficking, abuse and killing of Serows. Do not support operators that fail to be transparent about the source of their animals. Several thousand Serows are all that remain in the wild across the world. Report to authorities.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. No legal international trade of Chinese Serow meat or parts is permitted. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. National protections also apply in China, Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to authorities.
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. Request expert veterinary assistance. Animals should be under mild sedative for safety. Contain and do not approach until veterinarians or expert handlers arrive. Serows are known to be territorial and prefer to be alone or in small groups. Serows will make a loud whistle or a snort if they feel threatened.
traded_as: Meat, fur and various parts of the Serow, including horns, frontal bones, and leg bones are highly prized by local people for food and medicinal purposes.
common_trafficking: Meat and other body parts, like skulls and horns, are often transported by trucks and motorbikes.
disease_name: Anthrax, Brucellosis, Campylobacteriosis, Parapox Virus, Cryptosporidiosis, E. coli, Tularemia, Giardia, Leptospirosis, Salmonella, Plague.

They have thicker horns than other Serows and the horns are often times dark colored and curve backward.

habitat: Subtropical evergreen, broadleaf, deciduous, and bamboo forests.
basic_id_cues: These are medium sized primates that are golden yellow and gray in color. They are best identified by the tufts of hair framing their faces, which is most often white or gold. They usually have tufts of darker fur above their eyes on the forehead region. They have black bare faces with golden brown eyes. They also have long tails.
consumer_advice: DO NOT BUY Capped Langur or any derivative products. This species is classified as vulnerable as a result of extremely high levels of poaching both for its meat and the pet trade, and habitat loss.
enforcement_advice: INVESTIGATE. No legal international trade of Capped Langur or its parts is permitted. Any papers purporting to allow such trade are false or unlawful. National protections also apply. Examine each case for further investigative leads. Report to trusted authorities.
known_as: Capped Leaf Monkey, Capped Monkey, Bonneted Langur
first_responder: Avoid handling animal unnecessarily. ALWAYS wear gloves and a mask when dealing with primates as there is high zoonotic disease risk. Request expert veterinary assistance. Make sure animal has access to rehydrant (water, sugar water, honey, pedialyte) to fight off initial dehydration. Infants and juvenile primates need milk. Consult an expert for dietary requirements. Take care that infants are kept warm.
traded_as: Hunted extensively for meat, traditional medicine and for the pet trade
common_trafficking: Often trafficked as juveniles. Commonly sedated and hidden in boxes or luggage
